data.title: Brand Research
data.desc: Presence of texts relating to Election Day (Measure Day/Zero Hour Day), indicating: date, what citizens must do, why it is important – e.g. election posters showing the date, vote for...,  for...

data.title: Map Proposal
data.desc:
The countries turn lighter grey in turn. 
As the user votes, the names and flags of other voters around the world appear.
The lights on the map get brighter as more citizens go to play.
The formula normalises the weight of voters to compensate for differences in population size.
Ranking at the bottom, with or without names?

data.title: Project Review
data.desc:
project framework: The project conceptualizes SYNCHRO as a B2B institutional service provider rather than a state entity, facilitating temporal governance through data collection infrastructure.

Data Collection Mechanism: Users input personal metrics via NFC-coded devices, generating real-time feedback through LED arrays that visualize collective alignment with emergent standard. These standards self-define through accumulated user data rather than imposed benchmarks.

Physical Interface - the system employs immediate tactile responses: LED activation upon device placement, luminous intensity shifts across map infographics, and radial light movements indicating individual deviation from collective norms. This analog-digital hybrid maintains scenario coherence by rendering geopolitical temporal boundaries tangible.

Communication Strategy: institutional B2B messaging for SYNCHRO's facilitation services, versus public-facing "Our Hour Day" (provided by SYNCHRO) designed to cultivate popular support through accessible visual language.

data.title: Sensor technology research
data.desc:
Two main approaches were evaluated for token recognition:

NFC-based solution: NFC tags are passive (battery-free) and can store text or URLs interpreted by dedicated applications. However, this approach requires 24 NFC readers, raising concerns about cost and physical dimensions that require further investigation.
Physical property detection: Alternative identification methods include:

- Color recognition using TCS34725 sensor chips
- Distinct geometric shapes
- Different materials

The NFC approach faces two primary challenges: reader cost scalability and space constraints for 24 units. Physical property detection offers a potentially more cost-effective solution, though each method requires validation for reliability and discrimination capability in the intended application context.

data.title: Communication Kit Design
data.desc:
solutions for the token-recognition prototype: 
Solution 1) employs a single NFC sensor with a rotating mechanism: either two plates (one stationary, one rotating) or a pointer system. The rotation advances 15° per step, triggered by button press or timed intervals. However, cable tangling poses a significant structural risk due to continuous unidirectional rotation of LED and reader wires. 
Solution 2) utilizes 24 individual NFC readers positioned vertically along slot edges, with microswitches for token presence validation and RGB LEDs in the circular crown. This approach requires slots sized to accommodate tokens fully, increasing cost to approximately €100 but eliminating mechanical complexity. 
Solution 3) mirrors Solution 2's architecture with 24 RGB sensors, maintaining the same microswitch validation system and spatial requirements. Both multi-sensor solutions offer superior reliability despite higher material costs.

data.title: Parametric Experience Scoring
data.desc:
Parametric mathematical formula to calculate individual experience scores and generate country rankings. Citizens input their daily 24-hour distribution across sleep, work, leisure, and eating. A dynamic reference model continuously updates as the cumulative average of all submitted routines. 

Individual scores derive from calculating the distance between each citizen's routine and this evolving model—closer alignment yields higher scores. Normalization constrains scores between 0 (complete opposition to model) and 1 (identical to model). 

Country rankings emerge from averaging citizen scores within each nation. The "Zero Hour" goes to the country with the highest mean score. For the exhibition experience, ranking of non-Italian countries is randomized, while Italy's score starts from current standard averages and updates exclusively through exhibition visitor data input, without additional random data generation. 

This system creates a normalization bias, which is a self-reinforcing standard where conformity to the average becomes the definition of optimal experience.

data.title: Real-time Data Synchronization
data.desc: The user needs to be able to access its personal profile in our web app by receiving a randomly generated ID. This ID enables users to review data they previously entered into our device through the site/application at a later time. To support this functionality, the device must save the entered data to a spreadsheet in real-time. The device is Arduino-based and processes text data. The core technical question concerns the mechanism for transferring data from the device to a database or spreadsheet system.

data.title: Data Collection System
data.desc:
The data collection system from the physical device needs to captures measurements and transmits them to cloud storage. The system employs an ESP32 or Raspberry Pi microcontroller with internet connectivity to send data to either a Supabase database or Google Sheets via a custom API built with Google Apps Script. Each user interaction generates a unique ID linked to their measurement data. 

Four identification methods: on-device displays, thermal printers, web-app QR codes, and NFC tokens. The NFC approach involves users placing personal tokens on a reader integrated into the device, which associates their measurement with their stored ID. 

Critical technical challenges: testing NFC read reliability when multiple tokens are present simultaneously, determining optimal token thickness, and developing contingency plans—such as implementing 24 individual RGB readers or a rotating mechanical platform—if concurrent multi-token reading proves unfeasible.

data.title: Brand communication
data.desc:
Tone of voice
• Rigorous / Professional
• Formal
• Authoritative
• Informative - Clear and direct
• Objectivity

data.title: Interactive Map Design
data.desc: Twenty-four LED "lines", it divides the world into international time zones. The LED strips are not straight and evenly spaced but, as in all things political, individual countries have opted to adopt time standards that do not follow the expected patterns, resulting in the bent form of the tubes. LED strips light up one at a time to give an idea of voting around the world.

data.title: Storyboard proposal
data.desc:
1 - teaser: needs to establish the current state of global interconnection despite fragmented timekeeping, categorizing human activity into four measurable routines (sleep, eat, work, leisure).

2 - explanatory video articulating how political boundaries currently override geographic logic in time zone designation. Synchro operates through annual citizen data collection sessions where individuals submit routine information via ID-based identification, contributing to a competitive selection process that determines which nation sets the "Zero Hour" standard. The project functions as critical provocation, questioning whether algorithmic processing of behavioral data represents a more neutral temporal governance model than existing political frameworks, while simultaneously exposing how any standardization system (whether geographic, political, or data-driven) constitutes an act of power and imposition on lived experience.

data.title: Project Review
data.desc:
Visual Identity: The visual approach isn't fundamentally flawed, but it skews too playful. The negative space needs compositional refinement. These executions can work, but campaigns like "we believe every moment is meaningful" focus too heavily on describing actions rather than establishing context or scenarios.

Target Audience: We need clarity here. One option: expand to include companies alongside end users. The "conquer time" campaign had stronger conceptual grounding but poor execution.

Color & Tone: Current palette reads too optimistic. We need a more restrained, austere tone. The core idea holds, but the narrative needs reworking while maintaining the visual structure. The symbols need an alternative treatment. The overly positive tone of voice must be dialed back.

Prototype:
 -Size: Larger diameter works—38-40cm is viable since I don't need to handle it directly. Increased diameter allows for wider spokes.
- LED display showing ID/alphanumeric info.
- critical aspects: the current design risks to be too long to use and so could be problematc during the designed experience. an alternative is to use side knobs, exploit LED and colour themes anyway, a display, it's better to keep it physical 4 time slots - if we have a display, I can directly say what action I'm taking and no tokens.

Experience Flow:
1. User enters unique ID (no login required)
2. ID grants access to create account
3. Account links to ID
4. Web app: enter ID → view personal data
5. Includes map functionality
6. For other countries: establish regional ranges

Communication: must align with clean, concise, institutional language. 

teaser : should call for action and show the voting moment (which it should have its own name).

machine name: must highlight the theme of conflict (with name, visual rhetoric, language)

data.title: General project considerations
data.desc:
- This project addresses multiple stakeholder e.g. corporations, United Nations agencies, and nation-states, through a deliberately adversarial visual strategy. 
- The design employs inverted color schemes and confrontational aesthetics to challenge conventional data presentation norms. 
- Rather than explicit calls to action, the work embeds persuasive elements within its visual language, using stark symbolism and stripped-down communication to convey critical scenarios. 
- The approach rejects decorative language in favor of direct exposition, positioning data visualization as a site of political contestation. 
- By adopting "hostile" design choices (harsh color palettes, alternative symbolic systems) the project exposes how institutional actors employ metrics for governance and control.

data.title: Device Naming
Prototype redesign
data.desc:
Problem: The current design is too long action to complete the data entry with the 24 tokens, making it long and laborious to handle during experience.

Changes:
- length-based interface with side-mounted knobs that are used by the user to enter the daily data.
- LED color indicators for the 4 physical time slots 
- display screen to show which action is being taken

Benefit: With a display, users can see exactly what action they're selecting without needing any tokens.

data.title: Interactive Map Design
data.desc:
Dimensions: 42x32 cm
Operation: LED bands that light up one at a time to give an idea of voting around the world.

data.title: Scenario update
data.desc:
Annually, all citizens (identified by unique ID numbers) are summoned to designated facilities to submit their data and participate in selecting the nation that will control Zero Hour. 
This day naming proposal:
- reset day
- zero hour day
- sync day
- time shift day
- measure day

data.title: Project Review
data.desc:
Interface Design: Reduce colored dot size to mitigate toy-like aesthetic - avoid rotational mechanisms (requires bimanual operation, compromises stability). Recommended: minimal colored indicator + icon/text label. Color conventions provide baseline recognition, but contextual variation necessitates verbal/pictographic reinforcement.

Nomenclature: 
- Chronodex - preferred device designation: conveys technical precision, establishes "temporal indexing" semantics 
- Zero Hour Day - literal yet semantically accurate

Visual Elements & Brand Identity: Icons require accompanying text labels. Scale testing essential - complex iconography degrades at reduced dimensions, warranting simplification.

Logo: insufficient proximity between symbol and text requires adjustment. Implement superior iteration with integrated payoff. Conduct scale testing for legibility. Reduce tick marks, calibrate stroke weights - disparity between ring and typographic elements excessive. Typeface requires reinforcement.

Communication Framework - Critical gap: organizational partnership undefined. Recommend UN departmental affiliation - "UN [designation]" with "powered by Synchro" as subordinate attribution. 

Narrative: "We are Synchro - we collaborate with this entity advocating for: one world one time zone". Synchro maintains secondary positioning. Prioritize intrigue over comprehensive exposition.

Production: News broadcast format viable. Develop storyboard, integrate device interaction. Grey iteration effective. Sci-fi iconography redundant. Tile insertion demonstrates temporal inefficiency - three-step process superior.

data.title: Brand Palette and Logo
data.desc: Final color palette and logo spacing specifications

data.title: Prototype functionality
data.desc: The prototype operates through a dual LED ring system: an outer ring that illuminates white to indicate progress through inserted actions, and an inner ring that displays user-selected colors for each hour. A central button performs two functions: powering on the device (triggering a brief LED animation on the outer ring, displaying an ID on the screen, and optionally producing a startup sound for each voting session), and submitting data at the conclusion of voting. A single rotating knob functions as an hour selector, associating each hour with a value based on the currently active button as the user advances forward. Rotating the knob in the opposite direction deletes entries in a manner analogous to undo functionality, allowing users to backtrack to the point requiring correction.

data.title: Time Zone Map
data.desc:
Three distinct implementation strategies. 
- The first method involves a physical artifact combining a printed map with LED illumination controlled by Arduino. This approach presents fire safety considerations, requiring a protective plastic layer over the paper map. LED placement, either beneath (requiring high-intensity light sources) or above (necessitating tubular LED configurations), significantly impacts the technical requirements. 
- The second approach employs digital screens, offering greater modularity and direct access to existing data sources, though requiring careful design to conceal the screen's presence. 
- The third option utilizes projection technology, either for the complete visualization or exclusively for time zone data, though this raises spatial constraints. Each method presents distinct technical, material, and spatial trade-offs in representing temporal-geographic information.

data.title: Brand Comunication
data.desc: Synchro maintains secondary positioning. Prioritize intrigue over comprehensive exposition.

data.title: Web app prototype
data.desc: Final web app prototype, including a personal page that updates based on the score obtained and the global ranking

data.title: Project Reviews
data.desc:
Identity Development: Create a specific UN agency designation (e.g., "United Nations for Time Zone Normalization") that explains the program. The clock-based visual from the final poster works well but needs consistency across materials. The circular motif should recur throughout all posters. Current approach spreads elements across three poster types without coherence; eliminate redundancies.

Content Strategy: Replace vague terms like "establish" and "define" with direct language. Reduce excessive content: one component for SYNCHRO communication, one for the circular concept. Better structure the launch campaign.

Logo: Maximum 15pt with increased letter spacing. Column width approximately one and a half standard units.

Physical Map: Print on forex or 3-4mm plexiglass with map pieces mounted above and LED strips behind. Alternative: laser-cut wood/plywood with drilled holes at time zone markers, film layer, and LED backing. Frame required for cables and wall mounting. Size: A1. Test a section first. Use flexible LED neon strips programmable via Arduino.

Web Application: Make misalignment more evident in the radial visualization—better alignment with the standard should show more aligned SVG elements.

data.title: UN program logo research
data.desc:
Hypothetical UN department responsible for preventing measures (of time, space, etc.) from becoming a political weapon - security.

- UN Department for Global Measurement Integrity/Unification
- UN Department for Non-Political Standards
- UN Department for the Defense of Measurement Neutrality (DDMN)
- Department for Standards Protection and Security (DSPS)
- United Nations Office for Universal Time Regulation (UN-OUTR)
- United Nations Department for Global Time Coordination (UN-DGTC)
- United Nations Directorate for Temporal Harmonization (UN-DTH)
- Global Order of Standards (GOS)
- L'Ordine Globale degli Standard. Solenne, quasi
"nuovo ordine mondiale"
- Metric Integration Authority (MIA)
Integrare le metriche = integrare i comportamenti.
- Harmonized Measures Bureau (HMB)

data.title: Comunication update
data.desc:
- naming agency/United Nations department
- arrange text on poster zerohourday
- standardise posters for zerohourday day
- synchro and zerohourday with alternative color palette

data.title: Hardware testing
data.desc: Hardware testing procedure utilizing the ESP32 microcontroller platform. The testing protocol encompasses several physical interface components: a push button and tactile switch for discrete input, an RGB LED for multi-color output indication, a rotary encoder for analog input with discrete positioning (measured in degrees), a display module for visual feedback, and a standard switch for binary state control.

data.title: Project review
data.desc:
Department Naming: Rename to "Programme for [Time]" to better reflect temporal focus and align with UN conventions. This designation emphasizes the temporal aspect while maintaining institutional consistency.

Conceptual Refinement: Reconsider the neutrality concept given ISO's standardization role. Current messaging like "time is no longer neutral" reads as too pessimistic for UN communication standards. Adopt more assertive and positive language rather than verbose or negative framing.

Poster Compositions: Avoid catalog-style imagery. Choose between two clear visual directions: bold color approach or minimal graphic approach. The current hybrid lacks decisive visual language.

Tactile Text Design: Improve physical implementation by combining relief printing with black ink overlay, creating both tactile and visual hierarchy.

User Experience: Clarify flows, particularly around daily code generation functionality. The current interaction sequence lacks clarity about timing and user actions.

Logo Redesign: Avoid star-like appearance by converting internal radiating elements to small squares while maintaining the overall radiating structure. This preserves the temporal/circular concept while improving legibility and reducing unintended symbolic associations.

Motion Graphics: Develop video teasers using timezone reference lines as animated elements. Reference Royksopp's "Remind Me" music video for aesthetic direction—data visualization integrated with motion design.

data.title: Web app prototype
data.desc: Pe rsonal page update:misalignment more evident in the radial visualization (confrontation between personal data and mandated standard time)

data.title: Teaser storyboard
data.desc:
00:00-00:06 | Opening - problem
Black screen.
A deep sound signal, like a global broadcast.
A white line crosses the screen and breaks.
00:05-00:10 - Geopolitical scenario
The Greenwich meridian dissolves, replaced by multiple “pulsating” time axes.
VO: "Today, in a multipolar world, time is no longer neutral.
It defines trade, communication... everyday life."
Networks of cities light up one after the other. No drama: just order, regularity.
00:11-00:15 - UN intervention
Abstract UN logo (lines, orbits, no direct text).
A single timeline emerges from many, restoring order.
VO: ‘The United Nations envisions a new balance: a single global time zone governed by an independent and transparent institution.’
00:15-00:21 | One single time zone
Visual: View of the planet from satellite. Lights turning on in sequence.
OR map of time zones pulsing until only one lights up.
VO: ‘Its Department for Measurement Neutrality determines the world's reference time.’
00:21-00:24 | Invitation to Zero Hour Day, the annual mechanism
Visual: A simple circle closing in on itself, like a cycle coming full circle.
In the centre appears: ZERO HOUR DAY VO: "Every year, nations are evaluated.
The leading state earns the right to define the world's reference time."
